description.plain:
Michael Eugene Archer (born February 11, 1974), better known by his stage name D'Angelo (pronounced dee-Angelo), is an American R&B and neo-soul singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and record producer.

The allure of D’Angelo began in 1995 with his debut album Brown Sugar, where he emerged as a nostalgic figure in modern soul. Armed with a honeyed voice and hip-hop swagger, D’Angelo was equal parts Marvin Gaye and LL Cool J, the consummate musician and the coolest guy in the room. The album peaked at #22 on the Billboard 200 chart.

His sophomore album, January 2000’s Voodoo, was a near-perfect communion of buttery soul, Crisco-fried funk, and hip-hop thump. The album peaked at #1 on the Billboard 200 chart and earned him his first and second Grammy awards for Best R&B Album and Best Male R&B Vocal Performance for “Untitled (How Does It Feel).”

With the shock release of Black Messiah in December 2014, D'Angelo returned with his first album of new material in 14 years. The album earned him his third and fourth Grammy awards for Best R&B Album and Best R&B Song for “Really Love.”

songs.full_title: Unshaken by D'Angelo
songs.title: Unshaken

description.plain:
SPOILERS FOR RED DEAD REDEMPTION 2

“Unshaken” is a song that appears in Red Dead Redemption 2 at the gang’s lowest point. During a ride to Shady Belle, Arthur is left to reflect on what he has gone through, with the song suggesting he hopes to remain strong after losing so much.

The first of several points in Red Dead where the music becomes the main focus; this emphasis accompanied with the long, solitary ride feels a lot like its own version of the famous “Far Away” scene from the first game.

A reprised version of the song appears at a pivotal moment, at the end of chapter 6.

songs.full_title: Brown Sugar by D'Angelo
songs.title: Brown Sugar

description.plain:
Although it may seem so at first listen, “Brown Sugar” is not a love song about a dark-skinned woman. The track is an ode to marijuana, specifically the indica strain of the same name. This is done in the same personification style Rick James used for his 1978 classic, “Mary Jane.”

D'Angelo’s debut single peaked at #5 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart and #27 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The single earned D'Angelo a Grammy nomination in 1996 for “Best Male R&B Vocal Performance.” The song was also ranked #4 on Complex’s list of The Best Songs About Weed.

songs.full_title: Untitled (How Does It Feel) by D'Angelo
songs.title: Untitled (How Does It Feel)

description.plain:
“Untitled (How Does It Feel)” became notorious for its sexually charged video featuring a series of lingering shots of D'Angelo’s nude body that split the difference between mass voyeurism and personal intimacy.

However, the rapturous intensity in his lushly multi-tracked vocal performance still holds more weight than any pin-up shot could—swooping and diving, gliding smoothly over the sway of the beat only to punctuate it with a sharp hitch or an extension of his deceptively delicate falsetto into an intense wail. The musical backing only adds to that euphoria, with gospel-soul pianos direct from Aretha’s Muscle Shoals sessions intertwined with pre-Dirty Mind (but still dirty-minded) Prince guitars.

“Untitled (How Does It Feel)” was released as the third single from Voodoo and peaked at #2 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.

songs.full_title: Lady by D'Angelo
songs.title: Lady

description.plain: “Lady” is a collaboration between soul men D'Angelo and Raphael Saadiq that was released as the third single from Brown Sugar. The gold single peaked at #10 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #2 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. The song was later remixed by DJ Premier and featured D'Angelo’s EMI labelmate AZ, while the remix video featured cameos from fellow neo-soul star Erykah Badu and singer Faith Evans, who D'Angelo worked with on a remix of her single “You Used to Love Me.”

songs.full_title: Devil's Pie by D'Angelo
songs.title: Devil’s Pie

description.plain:
“Devil’s Pie” is a sparse funk diatribe on the excess of money and materialism in hip hop, with a minor reference to Five Percenter philosophy A Spin magazine columnist later cited “Devil’s Pie” as the album’s centerpiece, while also describing it as a “sweaty, head-nodding sermon against the evil seduction of hip-hop materialism.”

The track was released as a promotional single for Voodoo and peaked at #69 on the R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay chart.

songs.full_title: Send It On by D'Angelo
songs.title: Send It On

description.plain:
“Send It On” is dedicated to D'Angelo’s newborn son and was the first song recorded for Voodoo. Co-written by his former girlfriend and the mother of his son, singer Angie Stone, the contains lyrics concerning themes of honesty and faith in love, and features jazz trumpeter Roy Hargrove on the flugel horn.

“Send It On” was released as the fourth single from Voodoo and peaked at #33 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. The song contains a sample of Kool & the Gang’s January 1969 track, “Sea of Tranquility.”

songs.full_title: Left & Right by D'Angelo (Ft. Method Man & Redman)
songs.title: Left & Right

description.plain:
“Left & Right,” the second single from Voodoo features guest vocals by hip-hop duo Method Man and Redman who also co-wrote the song.
The song contains a sample from Eric B. & Rakim’s July 1987 single “My Melody.”

A single vinyl with A sides and B sides was released to promote the track in 1999, alongside a music video directed by Malik Sayeed.

“Left & Right” peaked at #18 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart and at #70 on the Hot 100 chart.

songs.full_title: One Mo' Gin by D'Angelo
songs.title: One Mo’ Gin

description.plain:
With a sonic similarity to someone stirring a humongous pot of gumbo somewhere in Haiti, this vaguely Prince-inspired musing finds D'Angelo singing to “the one that got away.” Amidst a bass line as lazy as D'Angelo’s vocal delivery is a wail of what appears to be a distorted organ with a sprinkling of D’s trademark electric piano wizardry.

“One mo'gin” is a contracted way of saying more and again.

description.plain:
“Spanish Joint” was one of the last songs to be recorded for Voodoo. In a May 2014 interview with Red Bull Music Academy, Russell Elevado describes how D'Angelo was wrapping up the sessions at Electric Lady Studios and then remembered that “Spanish Joint” had been left unrecorded:

songs.full_title: Shit, Damn, Motherfucker by D'Angelo
songs.title: Shit, Damn, Motherfucker

description.plain: “Shit, Damn, Motherfucker” details a man coming home to find his wife in bed with his best friend. In anger, he shoots both of him, leading to his arrest. The lyrics are straightforward and follow a simple plot, but D'Angelo’s singing is so expressive that you get to experience the protagonist’s full range of emotions as he contemplates the ordeal.

songs.full_title: Playa Playa by D'Angelo
songs.title: Playa Playa

description.plain:
Voodoo’s opening track is a braggadocious, sparse funk track that kicks off the album on a slightly menacing tone. This was the first track recorded for the album when D'Angelo was working on the Space Jam soundtrack and contains a lot of basketball references.

The first cut of “Playa Plays” leads into the last cut of The Roots album Illadelph Halflife which D'Angelo discusses at the 2014 RBMA.

songs.full_title: Cruisin' by D'Angelo
songs.title: Cruisin’

description.plain:
This quiet-storm love song by D'Angelo is a cover of Smokey Robinson’s 1979 hit of the same name. The track was released as the second single from his debut album and peaked at #10 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart and #53 on the Hot 100 chart.

Angie Stone, who dated D'Angelo at the time and was considered a huge influence in the making of Brown Sugar, mentioned to Essence Magazine that “Cruisin'” was the only song she could take credit for on the album.

“Cruisin'” appeared in between scenes on the third episode of Moesha and also on The Simpsons.

description.plain:
On Brown Sugar’s fourth single, D'Angelo illustrates his feelings for his long-time crush in hopes of finally making the move to pursue her. This was one of the songs he created in his Richmond, Virginia bedroom studio before connecting with producer/engineer Bob Power to record the track at Battery Studios in New York City.

The song was remixed by DJ Premier and twice by Erick Sermon—one version featuring Redman and the second version featuring a sample of Common’s single “I Used To Love H.E.R.”

songs.full_title: Chicken Grease by D'Angelo
songs.title: Chicken Grease

description.plain:
“Chicken Grease” was originally intended) for Common’s March 2000 album, Like Water for Chocolate, but after writing it, D'Angelo wanted it for his own album.

It contains an ambiguous harmony and bass by Pino Palladino, who evokes the playing style of James Jamerson, with spontaneously improvised variations-on-a-theme parts that sit back “in the pocket”.

The song contains background voices, which one review described as: “omnipresent party people channeled in from ‘What’s Going On’ and ‘Voodoo Chile’, laughin and carryin on all over.”

songs.full_title: I Found My Smile Again by D'Angelo
songs.title: I Found My Smile Again

description.plain:
This song, which first appeared on the 1996 Space Jam soundtrack, was actually an outtake from D'Angelo’s debut album, Brown Sugar.
According to ?uestlove, they had recorded ‘Playa Playa’, their first ever collaboration, for the soundtrack, but “the folks at Warner Brothers got freaked when they heard the final product”, and so this was lifted for a release. This also explains the basketball-themed lyrics of ‘Playa Playa’.

A remixed version, interpolating drums from the Detroit Emeralds' ‘You’re Getting A Little Too Smart’, was released on D'Angelo’s 2008 compilation The Best So Far …

Why are you sleepin' with my woman
Why are you sleepin' with my woman
This comes as a total surprise
I just can't believe my eyes
My best friend and my wife

[Hook: D'Angelo]
Shit, damn, motherfucker
Shit, damn, motherfucker
Shit, damn, motherfucker
Motherfucker, motherfucker, oh yeah babe

[Verse Two: D'Angelo]
Why the both of you's buck-balled naked?
Why the both of you's buck-balled naked?
I'm telling you what's on my mind
I'm 'bout to go get my nine
And kill both of y'all behind, check it out
[Hook]

[Verse Three: Chino XL]
(But I'm a creep)
She didn't mind
Splitting my pole in the beginning
I guess that's the bad luck
Didn't need to play no guitar strings or hit them cat guts
No she wanna act up
Filing for divorce and smashing my tapes like she Calvin Butts
But that's life
And I can't remember what souped me
When I made her my wife
Knowing fully that she was a groupie
Who wanted to use me
Somewhere I fell in love, treated like pavement
A stepping stone
My mack is in the basement
In amazement, she's so brazen, looking for a man that's rich
She'd leave her spouse and kid for someone more famous like Will Smith did
She tried to fade me
And with my best friend, that's crazy
With AZ, I'm Firm, but treated her like a Lady
Now I'm ready to riot
Cause I bought her a diamond ring
With enough carrots inside it
To supplement a rabbit's diet
She's my wife, you're not to touch her
You didn't hear me though
Now you in a wheelchair and she dead like R. Kelly's video
[Verse Four: D'Angelo]
Why the both of you's bleeding so much?
Why the both of you's bleeding so much?
Why the both of you's bleeding so much? So much yeah
Why am I wearing handcuffs? Why am I

[Hook]Embed
